events.title: Alberta Sovereignty Within a United Canada Act Passed

details.description: The Alberta government enacted the Sovereignty Act, authorizing the province to defy specific federal laws and regulations. Critics warned of constitutional risks and business uncertainty.
details.quote: "An act to protect Alberta from federal overreach," said Premier Danielle Smith.
impact: Legal challenges launched by private citizens and Indigenous groups
details.reversibility: Would require repeal by provincial legislature.

legalChallenges.description: Claim: Act infringes on Indigenous treaty rights.

sources.title: Alberta Sovereignty Act passes, Indigenous groups launch legal action

details.description: The UCP introduced Bill 18, which mandates social media companies to reduce the spread of hate content and misinformation. Critics claim it combines real harms and vague provisions.
impact: Unclear coordination with federal Bill C-36
details.reversibility: Bill may be amended or repealed by a new government.

sources.title: Alberta introduces new bill targeting online hate

details.description: To help with inflation, UCP approved $600 affordability payments to all households earning under $180,000/year and extra support to AISH recipients and families.
impact: NDP called for more targeted supports
details.reversibility: One-time, not permanent. No legal challenges.

events.title: Minimum Wage Frozen for Third Year

details.description: Alberta's minimum wage remains unchanged at $15/hour, causing Alberta to fall behind most of Canada. UCP government claims higher wages would reduce jobs.
impact: Adjusted for inflation, real wage has fallen 8%
Labor groups call for restoration to $17/hr
details.reversibility: New cabinet decision could adjust wage by regulation.

sources.title: Alberta to keep minimum wage frozen

events.title: Parents' Rights Act: LGBTQ Education Restrictions

details.description: Legislation requires parental notification for any pronoun or gender support discussions. Critics state it endangers trans and gender-diverse students.
impact: Teachers must seek parental approval for support
details.reversibility: The Act can be repealed or amended by a new government, but current law now restricts in-school supports.

legalChallenges.description: Challenging as a violation of Charter and privacy rights.
